course.subject: SOSC
course.name: Understanding Chinese Politics
course.description: After an historical and organizational introduction to Chinese politics, this course uses concepts such as political participation, bureaucratic politics, state-society relations, and political economy, to explain the development of the People's Republic of China.
course.prerequisites: SOSC 1300 or SOSC 1350

reviews.author: 您的綠子
reviews.title: Nice professor, but the course is a little challenging
reviews.comment_content:
The content is quite intriguing, especially if you are interested in politics or even researching Chinese history. However, for those who are not familiar with the history of China in the last century, learning the subject matter can be quite challenging.

1. Introduction
2. Understanding Rural China
3. Political Movements in Early Years of China
4. Reform and the Dismantling of the Commune system
5. The 1994 Fiscal Reform and its Impact
6. State-owned Enterprise and the Industrial Restructuring
7. Institutions and Economic Growth
8. State-business Relations in China
9. Social Conflict and Political Participation
10. New social Media in China
11. Political development of China
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor is very kind, and indeed, has extensive knowledge in the field.
reviews.comment_grading:
Class participation and question submission 20 / 20
Mid-term 19 / 20 (High is 19.5)
Final 18.5 / 20 (High is 19.5)
Term paper 38/ 40 (High is 38)

Finally, I got A. Overall, my scores were nearly highest, but the professor did not give out A+ grades in the small class, so nobody can got A+.
reviews.comment_workload:
1. Class participation and question submission: 20%

Every week, there are one to two readings, each consisting of approximately 20 pages or more. After completing the readings, students are required to write their own thoughts or questions, which will be recorded in attendance. During the second half of the class, students will participate in discussions and presentations based on the readings.

2. Two open-book in-class assessments (40%): essay questions

The exams aren't that hard, they're all covered in class and you need to take notes.

3. Term paper (research paper)/group project: (40%)

reviews.author: ykl
reviews.title: GOOD GRADE COURSE
reviews.comment_teaching: It is probably me, but I had troubles following during class even if I did most of the readings. So I can't really give a fair judgment on how well the professor gives lectures. However, he is a really helpful and nice professor.
reviews.comment_workload: This is a PG UG co-list course so the workload is quite heavy. Readings every week and class discussion is a main part of the class. Also, UG students need to write a 20 page research paper which is a lot more than what most courses require. Also, everyone has to give two short presentations on readings.
